review.title: Approval Voting and Incentives in Crowdsourcing
review.abstract: The growing need for labeled training data has made crowdsourcing an important part of machine learning. The quality of crowdsourced labels is, however, adversely affected by three factors: (1) the workers are not experts; (2) the incentives of the workers are not aligned with those of the requesters; and (3) the interface does not allow workers to convey their knowledge accurately, by forcing them to make a single choice among a set of options. In this paper, we address these issues by introducing approval voting to utilize the expertise of workers who have partial knowledge of the true answer, and coupling it with a ("strictly proper") incentive-compatible compensation mechanism. We show rigorous theoretical guarantees of optimality of our mechanism together with a simple axiomatic characterization. We also conduct empirical studies on Amazon Mechanical Turk which validate our approach.

sections.heading: 5 Robustness to the coarse beliefs assumption
sections.text: We used to start from the "rough assumption" that the employee's belief in any option, if it is not zero, is at least ρ. Then we designed Mechanism 1, which provides incentives to support the employee's beliefs. A natural question then arises: How does the mechanism work if the crude assumption of belief is violated? Does the mechanism break? In this section, we generalize the results presented earlier in the paper to the environment in which workers may have arbitrary beliefs. It turns out that our proposed mechanism continues to provide incentives for employees to act in a certain desirable way.

sections.heading: 6 Preliminary experiments
sections.text: In this section, the results of an evaluation of our proposed mechanism, Mechanism 1, are presented on the popular commercial crowdsourcing platform Amazon Mechanical Turk (mturk.com).The purpose of this preliminary experimental exercise is to conduct a fundamental review of whether our mechanism has the potential to work in practice. In particular, our goal is to evaluate the primary hypotheses underlying the theory: (i) whether workers are able to use the authorization process reasonably, (ii) whether the existence of the mechanism makes any difference, and (iii) whether there is worker resistance to the interface or mechanism for any reason. It is important to remember that conclusive experiments for mechanism design are generally quite expensive (workers take months to understand a new mechanism) and the budget. They are different from typical machine-learning experiments that require only existing benchmark data sets. In addition, the formulations may have an impact or significant influence on the behavior of the interface.

sections.heading: 6.1 Methods
sections.text: We conducted three separate series of experiments with over 200 workers in each experiment: • Identification of languages from displayed text (Figure 1) • Identification of animals in displayed images (Figure 2 (a)) • Identification of textures in displayed images (Figure 2 (b)).In each experiment, each worker was randomly assigned to one of four mechanisms. • The variable component of each mechanism was performed as a "bonus payment," based on the worker's assessment of performance in the gold standard questions, in addition to a guaranteed payment of 10 cents (this was αmin).The four mechanisms tested were: • Simple Selection Interface with additional payments: The worker must select a single option for each question. The bonus starts from zero and is additionally increased by a fixed amount for each correct answer. • Skipped single selection interface with multiplicative payments (Shah and Zhou, 2015): For each question, the worker can either select an option to skip the pre-selected question or decrease the total answer for each specific question by a detailed answer.

sections.heading: 7 General utility functions
sections.text: In this section, we consider a setting in which, instead of maximizing her expected payment, the worker aims to maximize the expected value of any benefit function of her payment. Let's consider any function U: R → R. In other words, for each payment made to the worker f (based on the evaluation of her answers to the gold standard questions), her benefit for that payment is U (f). The worker strives to maximize the expected value of U (f). We will demand that the function U be strictly increased and immutable. sections.heading: 9 Discussion and open problems
sections.text: This goal is to deliver high-quality labels for machine learning applications, at a low cost, using incentive mechanisms or aggregation algorithms or both. In this paper, we are following the earlier approach. We are taking a licensing vote based on the collection of marked data from crowdsourcing. We are designing an incentive mechanism through a principled theoretical approach and demonstrating appealing properties of our proposed mechanisms. Preliminary experiments conducted on Amazon Mechanical Turk substantiate the usefulness of this mechanism for practical scenarios. Our mechanism may also draw more experts to the crowdsourcing platform as their remuneration is significantly higher than that of the mediocre workers, unlike the remuneration mechanisms currently in use. We conclude with a discussion of closely related topics that require Merit investigation in the future.

The payment is a function of the agent’s response and the outcome of the event. The payment is called “strictly proper” if its expectation, with respect to the belief of the agent about the event, is strictly maximized when the agent reports her true belief. Proper scoring rules however provide a very broad class of mechanisms, and do not specify any particular mechanism for use. The mechanism proposed in the present paper may alternatively be viewed as the “optimal” proper scoring rules for eliciting supports of workers’ beliefs across multiple questions. Choosing the right interface. There are tradeoffs between various interfaces for crowdsourcing. For instance, the approval voting interface elicits the support of the belief whereas the single selection interface elicits the mode. Choosing among these two interfaces would depend on the application under consideration, and moreover, one may adaptively switch between the two depending on the data obtained. A natural question that one may further ask is, why not elicit the entire belief distribution itself? While the entire belief distribution seems to supercede the support and the mode, stating the distribution will also require much more time and effort from the workers, and often also suffer from a higher noise. These tradeoffs must be taken into account when choosing the interface for the application at hand. The coarse beliefs parameter. metadata.abstractText: The growing need for labeled training data has made crowdsourcing an important part of machine learning. The quality of crowdsourced labels is, however, adversely affected by three factors: (1) the workers are not experts; (2) the incentives of the workers are not aligned with those of the requesters; and (3) the interface does not allow workers to convey their knowledge accurately, by forcing them to make a single choice among a set of options. In this paper, we address these issues by introducing approval voting to utilize the expertise of workers who have partial knowledge of the true answer, and coupling it with a (“strictly proper”) incentive-compatible compensation mechanism. We show rigorous theoretical guarantees of optimality of our mechanism together with a simple axiomatic characterization. We also conduct preliminary empirical studies on Amazon Mechanical Turk which validate our approach.
